The presence of mutations could disrupt the operon, but if there are wild-type alleles present, maybe those can compensate, leading to some form of redundancy. The lac operon involves several genes, including the permease and repressor genes. When the operon is active, the repressor protein binds to the operator, preventing transcription. If the repressor isn't bound, RNA polymerase can transcribe the DNA, leading to the expression of genes like permease and rpoS. Now, the scenario says that some mutations are bypassed because of partial diploids. Since wild-type alleles are dominant, any disruption caused by mutations might not completely prevent the operon from working. In lac operon regulation, the repressor (rpoS) binds to the operator under lactose presence. If the repressor is missing (due to mutation), the operon remains off even without lactose. However, in this case, the partial diploids might provide enough functional alleles to maintain the operon's activity despite mutations. If the operon is induced (lactose present), the repressor should bind, preventing transcription. But if the repressor isn't present (because it's a partial diploid with wild-type alleles), then the operon can remain off unless induced again. Alternatively, if the operon is already on due to mutation, introducing lactose might cause it to stay on longer than usual. Answer this question step by step with only a single letter. Problem: Partial diploids can be produced in the bacterium E. coli for thelacoperon. As a consequence, some mutations can be bypassedin terms of their disruption of theoperonby productionof the partial diploids with wild-type alleles at the sitesof mutation. In each case the wild-type allele is dominant to its mutant homologue. Determine for each of the following partial diploids whetherenzyme production will result constitutively or inducibly(normally) when the inducer molecule is introduced: (a)i^+o^+z^-y^-a^- i^+o^cz^+y^+a^+ (b)i^-o^+z^+y^+a^+ i^+o^+z^+y^-a^- (c)i^+o^cz^+y^-a^- i^-o^+z^-y^-a^-

A. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Inducible, (c) No production of enzymes

B. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) No production of enzymes

C. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) Inducible, (c) Constitutive synthesis

D. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) Inducible

E. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Inducible

F. (a) Constitutive synthesis, (b) Inducible, (c) Constitutive synthesis

G. (a) No production of enzymes, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Inducible

H. (a) Inducible, (b) No production of enzymes, (c) Constitutive synthesis

I. (a) Inducible, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) No production of enzymes

J. (a) Inducible, (b) Constitutive synthesis, (c) Inducible

Answer with only a single letter. Answer:<|im_end|>
